abstract: HARRISON-David A. III. Of Prince George County, Virginia, on June 8, 2002, from complications of Alzheimer's disease at age 85. Born on August 30, 1916, to David A. and Elizabeth D. Harrison. Graduated from the Episcopal High School, Alexandria, VA, and received his undergraduate and law degrees from the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA. He was the husband of Mary Anderson Harrison who died in 1990 and the father of two sons, David A. IV of Richmond, VA, George A. of Prince George County, VA, and three daughters, Marjorie H. Webb of Greenwich, CT, Mary T.H. Keevil and Anne L.H. Armstrong, both of Manakin-Sabot, VA, and thirteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A brother also survives him, Richard D. Harrison of Richmond, VA, two sisters Anne H. Brown of Wilmington, DE, and Elizabeth H. Monroe of Bethesda, MD. His brother James G. Harrison died in 1989. He served in the army during the Second World War and attained the rank of captain. He spent his career at White & Case and Reynolds & Company (now Morgan Stanley) in New York City and retired to Flowerdew Hundred Farm in Prince George County, VA, in 1978 to pursue his love of farming, and to devote time to the architectural excavations on Flowerdew, which date back to 1617. He was closely affiliated to the University of Virginia and served as a trustee of the Law School Foundation, and a member of the Alumnae Association Board of Managers. Mr. and Mrs. Harrison endowed three professorships, the David A. Harrison Awards for Undergraduate Research that are given annually, and supported the football program and the rebuilding of the Law Grounds that carry his name. The Mary and David Harrison Institute of American History, Literature and Culture is under construction. A memorial service will be held on June 13 at Flowerdew Hundred Farm, Prince George County, VA, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name can be made to the University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department of Neurology, P.O. Box 800394, Charlottesville, VA 22908-0394.

abstract: NERKEN-Jean. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Ruth, Sara and the late Ira. Dear sister of Carl and the late Florence. Loving grandmother of Samantha Clare Karpinsky. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center, Singer Division, 170 East End Avenue, New York, New York 10028.   NERKEN-Jean. The Board of Trustees, Associate Board, League, Administration and Staff of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation deeply mourn the passing of Jean Nerken, Trustee and wife of Past Chairman Emeritus, Albert Nerken. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her children, Ruth and Sarah, son-in-law Robert, and her granddaughter. Jean and her late husband Albert founded the Nerken Center for Research at Parker, a nationally renowned center for geriatric research currently conducting significant studies related to Alzheimer's disease and associated dementia, anemia, depression, flu, osteoporosis, palliative care, and a host of other emerging health care issues related to aging. Thanks to the vision and generosity of Jean and Albert, The Nerken Center is at the forefront of advances in medicine that will help literally hundreds of thousands of older Americans live healthier, longer and more productive lives. Jean Nerken is an important part of the history of Parker and the ongoing mission to improve the quality of lives for older adults. She is part of an extraordinary legacy of caring & compassion that will always have a warm place in our hearts. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, Jan 27, 2002 at 10am, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 516-921-5757. Condolences can be sent to: Ruth Nerken, 55 W 74 St, NY, NY 10023. Barbara N. Kurshan, Chair of the Board, Barry T. Zeman, President Jonathan H. Freiberger, Steven Olken, Co-Chairs, Associate Board Florence Spencer, Suzanne Sussman, Lillian Wilner, Co-Presidents, Parker League   NERKEN-Jean. We mourn the loss of our dear friend with whom we shared many happy experiences. Elsie & Julie Diamond
lead_paragraph: NERKEN-Jean. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Ruth, Sara and the late Ira. Dear sister of Carl and the late Florence. Loving grandmother of Samantha Clare Karpinsky. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center, Singer Division, 170 East End Avenue, New York, New York 10028.

abstract: TRENTON: Bill For Wine Sampling At Stores; NEWARK: Police Search For Missing Woman:;.
snippet: TRENTON: Bill For Wine Sampling At Stores; NEWARK: Police Search For Missing Woman:;.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON: BILL FOR WINE SAMPLING AT STORES A bill in the New Jersey Legislature would make it legal to hold wine tastings at package stores, enabling store owners to compete with other states that already allow vintage sampling. Bill sponsors hope to increase wine sales, but opponents say the tastings would promote under-age drinking and drunken driving because it would be difficult to monitor how much people are drinking. "Today, consumers already have the right to sample wine in a certain venue before purchase," Deborah Dowdell of the New Jersey Restaurant Association said. "I think we have to look at the segment of the population that might abuse it." The concerns are unnecessary, according to bill's sponsor, Senator Ray Lesniak, who says it is consumer-friendly legislation intended to expose more people to different vintages.    (AP)
headline.main: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
headline.print_headline: Metro Briefing: New Jersey

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   3-10    Arafat Remains Confined; Tel Aviv Cafe Is Bombed  Israeli forces tightened their grip around Yasir Arafat, sealing the Palestinian leader into three rooms of his compound in the West Bank city of Ramallah, Palestinian officials said. But President Bush held Mr. Arafat largely responsible for his own predicament. Palestinian officials said that Israeli troops had announced over loudspeakers that they were preparing to storm the office itself in pursuit of wanted men.   1    A suicide bomber struck at a Tel Aviv cafe at the close of the Jewish Sabbath. Initial reports said only the bomber was killed, and 30 were wounded, one of them critically. Shortly after the blast, the Al Aqsa Brigades, a terror group associated with Mr. Arafat's Fatah movement, claimed responsibility.   1

abstract: ENGLAND: Invensys Sells Division:; GERMANY: Economic Growth Slow Again; IRELAND: Chief Faces Investors;.
snippet: ENGLAND: Invensys Sells Division:; GERMANY: Economic Growth Slow Again; IRELAND: Chief Faces Investors;.
lead_paragraph: ENGLAND: INVENSYS SELLS DIVISION: Struggling to reduce a mountain of debt, Invensys, a British manufacturer of factory controls, said it had agreed to sell its sensor business, which is based in Shelby, N.C., to Honeywell International , based in Morristown, N.J., for a net $394 million. Invensys said the sale meant it had completed 60 percent of its $2.3 billion debt-reduction program. The company's shares rose 7.25 percent. Invensys is still trying to sell Rexnord, an engineering firm based in the United States.

abstract: EUROPE IRELAND: DRUG STUDY HALTED The Elan Corpora- tion of Ireland and the American Home Products Corporation halted a study of an Alzheimer's treatment because of safety concerns, setting off the biggest one-day drop in shares of Elan in more than two years. The companies suspended the trial after four patients displayed symptoms of inflammation in the central nervous system. Investors said the experimental drug, known as AN-1792, was one of the most promising products in Elan's labs.

abstract: Barbara A. Simeone, the daughter of Nancy and Gerard Simeone of Belleville, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Kenneth Maiese, the son of Margaret Maiese of Mount Laurel, N.J., and the late Charles Maiese. The Rev. William F. Gavin, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Church in Philadelphia.    The bride is a vice president and the director of planning and administration at Verizon Capital Corporation, an investment subsidiary of Verizon Communications in New York. She graduated from Seton Hall University and received an M.B.A. degree from Fairleigh Dickinson University. Her father retired as an electronic technician for AlliedSignal, a maker and supplier of automotive components, in Teterboro, N.J. Her mother retired as an employment counselor at Snelling & Snelling, a personnel services company in Bloomfield, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Barbara A. Simeone, the daughter of Nancy and Gerard Simeone of Belleville, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Kenneth Maiese, the son of Margaret Maiese of Mount Laurel, N.J., and the late Charles Maiese. The Rev. William F. Gavin, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Church in Philadelphia.

abstract: Op-Ed article by Michael J Sandel, member of President's Council on Bioethics, on his personal views on cloning as Senate prepares to take up anti-cloning legislation; says at issue is whether to prohibit scientists from using cloning techniques to create embryos for stem cell research or to treat various diseases; says some oppose research cloning on grounds that embryo is a person, while others support embryonic stem cell research, provided it uses spare embryos left over from fertility clinics; says if creation and sacrifice of spare embryos in infertility treatment is morally acceptable, why is creation and sacrifice of embryos for stem cell research not also acceptable; says opponents of research cloning cannot have it both ways: they cannot endorse creation and use of excess embryos from fertility clinics and at same time complain that creating embryos for regenerative medicine is exploitative (M)
snippet: Op-Ed article by Michael J Sandel, member of President's Council on Bioethics, on his personal views on cloning as Senate prepares to take up anti-cloning legislation; says at issue is whether to prohibit scientists from using cloning techniques t...
lead_paragraph: As the Senate prepares to take up anti-cloning legislation, all sides agree that human cloning to create designer babies should be banned. At issue is whether to prohibit scientists from using cloning techniques to create embryos for stem cell research or to treat diseases like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and diabetes.

abstract: BAKER-Richard T. of Gulf Stream, FL and Lake Leelanau, Michigan passed away on December 7, 2002. Dick was born September 4, 1917 in Anderson, IN. His parents were Leslie & Rachel Baker. He was educated in the Anderson schools and became an avid basketball player and played on the state championship team in 1935 when he was a senior. He was elected to Indiana Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993. He graduated from Ohio State University in 1939. He was voted Basketball All-American by the Associated Press. He and his college sweetheart, Marty, were married in 1939 and he joined the firm of Ernst & Ernst in Cleveland, OH as a junior accountant. He spent 13 years in the St. Louis office and then moved back to the Cleveland office. He was made Managing Partner of Ernst & Ernst in 1964 and retired from the firm in 1977. After his retirement he served on the Board of Directors of GE, Hershey Foods, International Paper, Textron, Louisiana Land & Exploration and Anheuser Busch. He received an Honorary Doctorate of Accounting from Angola University, IN; Honorary Doctorate of Accounting from Ohio State University; was elected to the Accounting Hall of Fame at OSU and elected to the Business Hall of Fame in Cleveland, OH. In 1984 he was elected Outstanding Director of the year. Dick was a passionate golfer (with eight hole-in-ones to his credit) and an avid fly fisherman. He was a member of Gulf Stream Golf Club, Little Club, The Ocean Club and Double Eagle Golf Club. Former member of Augusta National Golf Club and Turtle Lake Club, Pepper Pike Golf Club, the Question Club. Mr Baker leaves behind his cherished wife of 63 years, Martha Brown Baker. He is survived by daughter Jane Baker of San Francisco, daughter Laura Baker (Lewis Lubin) of Berkeley, CA and son Richard T. Baker, Jr (Cheryl Madsen) of San Francisco and son-in-law David Wolman of Philadelphia. He was pre-deceased by his daughter Anni Baker Wolman in 1999. He is survived by granddaughters Amanda Baker Wolman, Lily Baker Lubin and Ruby Renne Madsen Baker and by grandsons Alex Baker Lubin, James Kristiaan Madsen Baker and Tommy Baker Madsen. Services will be held Wednesday, January 15, 2003, 10:30 AM at the First Presbyterian Church, 33 Gleason St, Delray Beach, FL. Interment will be in Lake Leelanau, MI. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your local Alzheimer's Assn.

lead_paragraph: The patient is 60, and she has been happily taking estrogen for 20 years, ever since her uterus and ovaries were removed. Now, she would like to stop. But when she tries, she is miserable. Hot flashes leave her drenched in sweat, sometimes as often as every half hour, and she seems to be getting more uncomfortable every day.

abstract: KARTEN-Julia. Of Spring Valley and New York City died on October 5 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. She was surrounded by her beloved children and grandchildren. Only 16 at the outset of WWII, Julia, who met her husband Isidore in the Polish underground, fought by his side in the Jewish Resistance. Coming to America with only a borrowed blouse on her back, Julia managed to rebuild her life. Landing at Pier 56 in New York Harbor, at 20 years of age with a newborn child, no close relatives and not a word of English, Julia became the nurturing life force at the center of her family. She was truly a woman of valor. Equally adept at running a business as she was at running a home, she brought her intelligence, sensitivity, artistic talent, and concern for people to everything she did, whether it was volunteering to be a Girl Scout leader or managing a successful textile business and a high-rise apartment building in the heart of Manhattan. But one of Julia's biggest sense of achievements came from her and Izzy's active involvement in a multitude of philanthropies, including education in the form of scholarships, Benefactor of the International Society of the Yad Vashem both in America and Israel, as well as the endless donations to hospitals, schools, and synagogues around the world. Julia is survived by her loving children, Berne and Jim Bookhamer, Marcia and Yakov Toledano, and Harry and Danielle Karten as well as her eight dedicated grandchildren. She was above all a strong, courageous woman who fought until the end. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 7, at 12:30 PM at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street. Donations can be made to the Alzheimers Foundation, the Scholarship Fund at Park East Day School and the American Diabetes Foundation.     KARTEN-Julia. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Julia Karten, matriarch of the Karten family, Holocaust survivor, who with her late husband, Trustee Isidore Karten, were benefactors of our Synagogue. Together they transmitted to their children Berne (James) Bookhamer, Harry (Danielle) Karten, Marcia (Yakov) Toledano, a love for Torah and the Jewish people. May they and their children find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Services at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, Monday, October 7, 12:30 PM. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President     KARTEN-Julia. The Board of Trustees, administration and faculty extend their deepest sympathy to Trustee Harry (Danielle) Karten on the loss of his beloved mother, Julia Karten, and to her daughters Berne (James) Bookhamer and Marcia (Yakov) Toledano. The generosity of the Karten family has strengthened Jewish education and has benefited the children of our day school. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School

abstract: Dr Evan Hadley, associate director at National Insitute on Aging, holds that frailty among older adults is not foregone conclusion; new research suggests that frailty could be considered definable syndrome and linked with proteins involved in chronic inflamation; doctors hope to learn more about diagnosis and treatment in near future; although maintaining or increasing muscle does appear to help most individuals, it is not guaranteed protection against becoming frail; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: Doctors know them when they see them, or so they say. They call them the frail elderly. The assumption is that frailty goes along with aging, as inevitable as white hair and wrinkles. It is the price to be paid for living to an advanced age.

abstract: Editorial holds claim by Raelian religious sect that Clonaid has cloned baby girl is likely to revive political debate about how to deal with issues of whether to ban reproductive cloning--attempt to fully duplicate a human--and therapeutic cloning, method of producing stem cells that could cure wide range of human diseases (M)
snippet: Editorial holds claim by Raelian religious sect that Clonaid has cloned baby girl is likely to revive political debate about how to deal with issues of whether to ban reproductive cloning--attempt to fully duplicate a human--and therapeutic clonin...
lead_paragraph: In a claim worthy of a P. T. Barnum sideshow, a science-dabbling group of futurists who believe in extraterrestrials and ''downloading'' human clones with born-again personalities stepped forth yesterday to announce the birth of a baby girl cloned from her mother. No proof was offered of this sensational and scientifically controversial assertion. A skeptical world is left boggled, with DNA testing of the supposed offspring by independent scientists promised by the self-proclaimed cloners in the next few weeks. It would all be an occasion for ghoulish bemusement if the science of responsible cloning research were not advancing so rapidly with hopes of truly therapeutic possibilities for humanity.
headline.main: Ersatz Eve
headline.print_headline: Ersatz Eve

abstract: Scientists are coming to realize that inflammation, body's basic defense mechanism, may underlie many common chronic diseases that come with aging; hope study of inflammation will lead to new ways of treating variety of such illnesses; role of inflammation in causing heart attacks cited; diagram; drawing; photos (M)
snippet: Scientists are coming to realize that inflammation, body's basic defense mechanism, may underlie many common chronic diseases that come with aging; hope study of inflammation will lead to new ways of treating variety of such illnesses; role of inf...
lead_paragraph: At the slightest provocation -- a mosquito bite, a mild sunburn, a tiny splinter -- the body mounts a hair-trigger defense, sending cells and natural chemicals to destroy dirt or germs and repair the damage. As a result, the site of injury becomes red, swollen, warm and painful -- inflamed.
headline.main: Body's Defender Goes on the Attack
headline.print_headline: Body's Defender Goes on the Attack

abstract: New Chancellor, New Retirements.
snippet: New Chancellor, New Retirements.
lead_paragraph: Two veterans of the New York City school system who played important roles under past chancellors have decided to retire just months after moving to the Tweed Courthouse. BURTON SACKS, a liaison to the community school districts and troubleshooter for many a chancellor, is retiring after 33 years in the system. WILLIAM P. CASEY, who helped shape the instructional agenda under Chancellors HAROLD O. LEVY and RUDY CREW, is leaving after 37 years. Education officials said both men felt marginalized under Chancellor JOEL I. KLEIN, whose inner circle does not include many old-timers. A spokesman for Mr. Klein said the two men were simply ready to retire.

abstract: Editorial says slow pace of stem cell research makes it clear that compromise approach toward this controversial research fashioned by Pres Bush is not working; says that if National Institutes of Health, which is striving to make more cell lines available, does not find way to expedite progress, Congress may need to step in with remedial legislation
snippet: Editorial says slow pace of stem cell research makes it clear that compromise approach toward this controversial research fashioned by Pres Bush is not working; says that if National Institutes of Health, which is striving to make more cell lines ...
lead_paragraph: When Nancy Reagan, the State of California and leading medical scientists all express frustration within days of each other over the slow pace of stem cell research, it seems clear that the compromise approach toward this controversial research fashioned by President Bush is not working. If the National Institutes of Health, which is striving diligently to make more cell lines available, does not find a way to expedite progress, Congress may need to step in with remedial legislation.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A2-7    3 Die in Bomb Attack On Pakistan Hospital  A bomb attack on a Christian hospital killed three Pakistani nurses and wounded 23 people as they left a chapel. The assault, the second on a Christian Western target this week, raised fears that Islamic militant groups are mounting a fresh challenge to one of the United States' most important allies in the campaign against terrorism, President Pervez Musharraf.   A1    U.S. Warning on Court  The Bush administration is warning foreign diplomats that their nations could lose all American military assistance if they join the International Criminal Court without signing an exemption for Americans serving in their countries.   A1

abstract: Five-part documentary series The Secret Life of the Brain, set for Channel 13, explores how brain develops over lifetime, focusing on key stages of human development; executive producer David Grubin comments, interview; photos (M)
snippet: Five-part documentary series The Secret Life of the Brain, set for Channel 13, explores how brain develops over lifetime, focusing on key stages of human development; executive producer David Grubin comments, interview; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IN trying to convey a sense of the brain's complexity, neuroscientists are fond of mind-boggling comparisons. Did you know that your brain has more connections than there are stars in the universe? A bit of your brain about the size of a sand grain contains 100,000 neurons and a billion synapses. Somehow this three-pound lump of tissue generates thoughts and emotions, holds memories, creates movements, makes possible the creative acts peculiar to our species and gives rise to the mysterious sense of consciousness.

abstract: For Collegiate Chorale  WEDNESDAY -- Florence Quivar, a Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, will perform at the Knickerbocker Club, 2 East 62nd Street, to celebrate the Collegiate Chorale's 60th anniversary and to raise money for the group's efforts to promote vocal arts and develop young audiences. The evening begins at 6 with cocktails and dinner; the recital is at 8 and dessert at 9. Tickets, $500, or $250 for the concert and dessert reception alone, from (917) 322-2140.    Tasting in Central Park  WEDNESDAY -- A tasting dinner under a tent in Central Park will raise money for the Central Park Conservancy. The evening begins at 6:30 with cocktails on the Bethesda Terrace, with dinner at 7 and dancing to the music of Andy Anderson, a D.J. Tickets, $250, from (212) 310-6619.

abstract: What a difference a few house calls can make. Sometimes even the doctors feel better.    There was a time, before physicians started seeing Rosalia Morales at her home, when this very ill 66-year-old widow was not getting any medical care at all. Mrs. Morales suffers from Alzheimer's disease and has had several strokes. She is bedridden and cannot feed herself.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a few house calls can make. Sometimes even the doctors feel better.
headline.main: House Calls: How Physicians Heal Themselves
headline.print_headline: House Calls: How Physicians Heal Themselves

abstract: Editorial says Pres Bush has called for promising area of cloning research to be banned as unethical, while 40 Nobel Prize winners call for cloning of embryonic cell clusters for research and therapeutic purposes; says nub of dispute is whether very early embryos are human life that should not be destroyed, or primitive clusters of cells; says Nobel laureates surely have better grasp of science than Bush; says most troubling aspect of Bush's remarks was their black-and-white, even apocalyptic tone
snippet: Editorial says Pres Bush has called for promising area of cloning research to be banned as unethical, while 40 Nobel Prize winners call for cloning of embryonic cell clusters for research and therapeutic purposes; says nub of dispute is whether ve...
lead_paragraph: President Bush and 40 Nobel Prize winners went head to head yesterday on the controversial issue of human cloning. The president, in a speech, said a promising area of cloning research should be banned as unethical. But from our perspective the Nobelists, who released a letter, held the higher moral ground in focusing on the great promise of cloning for curing intractable diseases.
headline.main: The President's Narrow Morality
headline.print_headline: The President's Narrow Morality

abstract: GOLDMAN-Lillian. On August 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol Goldman. Loving mother of Allan Goldman, Diane Goldman Kemper, Amy Goldman and Jane Goldman. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie Pittel, Cindy Blotner, Robin Kemper, Steven Goldman, Tris Goldman, Sara Arno, Solina Lewis Goldman and Michael Lewis Goldman. Great grandmother of Justin, Samantha and Bennett Pittel and Sabrina and Melissa Blotner. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday 7-9 PM. Services Thursday, August 22, 2002, 10AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.   GOLDMAN-Lillian. Dearest Lillian, beloved matriarch of the Goldman family, thank you for loving us so selflessly, so completely, for so long. We have been blessed-and will continue to be so-by your warmth, wisdom, and wit; your strength, bravery, and resilience. You are our inspiration and our anchor and we are forever grateful. Love always, Allan, Dee Dee, Amy, Jane and grandchildren and great grandchildren   GOLDMAN - Lillian. With compassion, insight, magnanimity, elegance, and grace, you courageously confronted life's challenges and joyfully savored life's gifts with gratitude. The pinnacle of loving kindness, you embraced us unfailingly and exemplified the ways of righteousness. Your legacy will linger as your spirit soars. Love, Diane and Robin   GOLDMAN - Lillian. With deepest sorrow we mourn the loss of our beloved mother and grandmother, the matriarch of our family. Her generous spirit, warmth and kindness extended to family, friends, and community. Our beautiful memories of her will live on in our hearts. Allan, Stephanie, Cindy, Steven & Tris   GOLDMAN-Lillian. Our entire family deeply mourns the sudden loss of Lillian. For decades, she touched the lives of all of us with her love and graciousness. She was a woman of incredible strength, wit and style. Harriet and David Goldman, Barbara and Wayne Prigoff, Carol and Andrew Machover, Ellen and David Horowitz   GOLDMAN - Lillian. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved aunt, Lillian Goldman, a wonderful woman-generous, loving and inspirational. We will miss her and always remember her style, great dignity and grace. Victoria and Lloyd Goldman and Family   GOLDMAN-Lillian. Dearest Nanny, you'll be the sun in our skies, the laughter in our wind and the love that we feel in our hearts. Never too far will you be. Steffi, Andrew, Justin, Samantha and Bennett    GOLDMAN-Lillian. Aunt Lillian, gracious, strong, elegant lady of many talents. We will miss your wit & joie de vivre. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Lillian Goldman, a cherished friend who expressed a dedication to improving the lives of those less fortunate through her extraordinary generosity. Mrs. Goldman and her late husband, Sol, were philanthropic giants, deeply devoted to Jewish and humanitarian causes. Their unwavering support of UJAFederation enabled many of our beneficiary agencies to expand, thrive, and touch the lives of many New Yorkers. The Sol Goldman YM-YWHA of The Educational Alliance, a UJA-Federation beneficiary agency, is a lasting tribute to their countless contributions. Mrs. Goldman's dedicated efforts on behalf of education, particulary for women and the underprivileged; the cultural arts; and health research will be felt for generations to come. Mrs. Goldman's extraordinary legacy lives on in the continuing efforts of her children. Her daughter, Jane Goldman Lewis, and her son, Allan, are leaders in the Jewish community. Jane's philanthropic spirit lends tremendous support to many of the socialservice programs provided by our agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Goldman's children, Allan, Diane, Amy, and Jane; to her grandchildren and to her great-grandchildren; & to the entire Goldman family. May her memory be a blessing. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.   GOLDMAN-Lillian. The Offices and staff of Appraisers & Planners, Inc. extend their heartfelt sympathy to the family of Lillian Goldman; to Allan, Jane, Diane and Amy, and their children. Their profound personal loss is shared by the countless number of benefactors of her kindness, generosity and charity for so many years. She was a highly respected, gracious lady, possessed of great strength, wisdom, wit and spirit who made an immeasurable contribution to the business, professional, cultural, medical and academic communities of New York and beyond. Her presence will be sorely missed by all of us privileged to know her and her family, and to serve them professionally over the years. James L. Levy, President   GOLDMAN-Lillian. The Alzheimer's Association family deeply mourns the passing of our friend and benefactor, Mrs. Lillian Goldman. We extend heartfelt sympathies to her daughter Amy Goldman and the entire Goldman family. Lillian has graced our Association with her interest, passion and generosity. Her extraordinary commitment to bettering the lives of families living with Alzheimer's disease, through research, has benefited and inspired many. We are profoundly grateful to have known and worked with her. Alzheimer's Association National Board of Directors The N.Y. Rita Hayworth Gala Steering Committee and The Zenith Fellow Members   GOLDMAN - Lillian. The Trustees, Officers and staff of the Educational Alliance mourn the passing of Lillian Goldman whose family continues to play an active and supportive role in our organization. Our Y on 14th Street is named after her husband Sol. Her children were the initial major supporters of the Y's revitalization. Her niece Victoria Goldman and nephew Marvin Israelow are Board Vice Presidents. The Goldman family philanthropy continues to support the Alliance's programs and services. We offer our sincere condolences to her children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews and extended family. Richard A. Cantor, President Robin Bernstein, Exec. Dir.   GOLDMAN-Lillian. The partners and staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield extend their deepest condolences to the family of our most cherished friend and client. To our senior partners, Bert and Herbert, Lillian's beloved, departed husband Sol, and their wonderful children, Allan, Jane, Deedee and Amy, you will always be part of our extended family. Lillian was truly unforgettable. Her widespread charitable endeavors will bear testament to her for many years to come. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her & benefited from her good works. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield   GOLDMAN - Lillian. The Board, staff, and members of the New York City Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society mourn the loss of a generous friend and ally in the fight against MS. Her philanthropic commitment led to the creation of the Lillian Goldman Endowment to advance the study and treatment of the cognitive, affective and psychological symptoms of MS, which will greatly accelerate our understanding of and ability to treat MS. We extend heartfelt sympathy to our dedicated Trustee, Robin Kemper, and the entire Goldman family whose extraordinary philanthropy benefits so many.   GOLDMAN - Lillian. The Board of Directors and staff of Lighthouse International mourn the loss of Lillian Goldman, a longtime friend and supporter of our organization. Her generosity over the years has enhanced The Lighthouse Music School and our Child Development Center, and continues to further our mission of helping people of all ages overcome the challenges of vision impairment. We extend our sincere condolences to her son, Allan, and to her entire family. William B. Follett, Chairman, Board of Directors Barbara Silverstone, DSW, President and CEO Lighthouse International   GOLDMAN - Lillian, The Dean and Faculty of Yale Law School mark with profound sadness the passing of our longtime friend and generous benefactor, Lillian Goldman. She will be warmly remembered for her devotion to Yale Law School and her support of its students through scholarships and through the revitalization of our magnificent law library, which now bears her name. It stands as a testament to her love of knowledge and learning. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Anthony T. Kronman Dean Yale Law School   GOLDMAN-Lillian. Lillian's longstanding and enthusiastic support of children's education and horticulture typifies her visionary philanthropy & far-reaching contributions to the civic and cultural life of New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Amy and family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Gregory Long, President   GOLDMAN - Lillian. Our hearts reach out to comfort Allan, Diane, Amy, Jane, Ben and their families on the loss of their beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. A sister-in-law and aunt with elegant style, a love of the arts, unique insight, and an extraordinary legacy. Through the hearts of her loved ones, Lillian will achieve everlasting life. Elaine Koenigsberg Jeri and David Glaser Kim and Barry Douglas Craig and Jill Koenigsberg   GOLDMAN-Lillian. We mourn the passing of our beloved mother and adored grandmother. During these last precious weeks in your summer home, surrounded by loving family, you showed your characteristic strength, dignity and humor. abstract: Article explores role that estrogen plays in alleviating symptoms of menopause and controversy over estrogen replacement therapy in light of early and abrupt halting of Women Health Initiative study of combination drug Prempro; notes benefits of temporary use of estrogen to weather hot flashes, night sweats and vaginal dryness have not been challenged; use of Prempro, combination of estrogen and progestin, by healthy postmenopausal women has shown small but statistically significant increase in breast cancer, heart attacks, stroke and blood clots that outweighed lower risk of hip fractures and colon cancer; photos; drawings; graphs, charts (L)

lead_paragraph: Susan McGee of Bethesda, Md., and Jane Quinn of Brooklyn were not planning to take hormones at menopause. But after many months of sleep disrupted nightly by drenching sweats and changes of bedclothes, they gave in.

abstract: WEXLER-Jack. Died peacefully surrounded by family on December 26, 2002. Unbounding kindness and generosity were his life's work. Cherished father to Ann and Robert Fromer and Nina and Gary Wexler. Adored grandfather to Tony and Amy Fromer, Yvette and Roger Mincheff, Michal Fromer and Elana and Freddy Wexler. Great grandfather to Alexandra and Madeline Fromer. A graduate of the Cooper Union School, he pursued painting and commercial art in his early years. Together with his brother-in-law Morton Rechler, he established the real estate development firm, The We're Group, a partnership that has lasted over half a century. His greatest partnership however, was with his wife Ruth, which lasted for 68 years until her passing in 2001. Together they loved without reservation, their family and friends and the charitable and non-profit organizations they worked so hard for. Among those closest to their hearts were the Migdal Ohr School in Migdal, Hamek and the 6000 children the school educated and nourished, Hadassah, Southern Poverty Law Center, Yeshiva University, Nassau County Museum of Art, UJA, Temple Israel of Great Neck, Zahal Disabled Veterans, ADL, Guide Dogs for the Blind, Alzheimer's Foundation, Jewish National Fund, ORT, The Maccabi World Union, Israel Tennis Centers, Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Hebrew University, as well as numerous U.S. veterans' organizations. He was an inspiration to all who knew him, and his wonderful wit and never ending sense of humor lasted to the very end. He will be sorely missed and always remembered by his family and all those lives he touched. Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. Friday, December 27th, at 1:30 P.M.    WEXLER-Jack. Hadassah, The Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., mourns the passing of Jack Wexler, beloved husband of Ruth, of blessed memory. As a member of the Society of Major Donors, Jack was a generous benefactor of Hadassah, who was devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. His legacy will live on through the visionary projects he supported at the Hadassah Medical Organization. We extend our deepest condolences to his children, Ann and Robert Fromer and Gary and Nina Wexler, and the entire family. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, President    WEXLER-Jack. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are saddened by the passing of Jack Wexler, beloved father of Ann Fromer. Ann and her husband, Robert, are cherished friends of UJAFederation who continue to touch thousands by their generosity and commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes. Our hearts and prayers are with Ann and Robert, their family, and all who mourn Mr. Wexler's loss. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. Erika Witover, LI Chair Stuart Tauber, LI Director    WEXLER-Jack. The Partners of Hartman & Craven LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of our friend and mentor, Jack Wexler. Mr. Wexler was a pioneer of commercial real estate development on Long Island who, together with his late wife Ruth and their family, sponsored humanitarian and philanthropic works both here and in Israel. Our sincere condolences to the Wexler and Fromer families.    WEXLER-Jack. We mourn the passing of a beneficient friend, advisor, and humanitarian. Jack is now with his beloved Ruth. Their absence leaves a cavernous void, which can only be filled by the loving memories held by Ann, Gary, Robert, and Nina, and their children. Allyne and Fred Schwartz and The Auschwitz Jewish Center Foundation    WEXLER-Jack. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

abstract: DeAnn Carol Fairfield and Paul MacGregor Work were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas W. Sweat, a United Methodist minister, at Evelynton Plantation in Charles City, Va.    The bride, 32, is a business consultant in San Francisco who is working on business development and market strategy for a biotechnology company. She graduated from Princeton and received a law degree cum laude from Harvard. She is the daughter of Janice and Thomas Fairfield of Gloucester, Va. Her father is a manager in Newport News, Va., for aircraft carrier contracts and pricing for Northrop Grumman. Her mother, who is retired, was a secretary in the guidance office at York High School in Yorktown, Va.
lead_paragraph: DeAnn Carol Fairfield and Paul MacGregor Work were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas W. Sweat, a United Methodist minister, at Evelynton Plantation in Charles City, Va.

abstract: Frankie Albert, first T-formation quarterback in modern college football who was two-time All-American at Stanford and later played for San Francisco 49ers, dies at age 82; photo (M)
snippet: Frankie Albert, first T-formation quarterback in modern college football who was two-time All-American at Stanford and later played for San Francisco 49ers, dies at age 82; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Frankie Albert, the first T-formation quarterback in modern college football as a two-time all-American at Stanford and later a star with the San Francisco 49ers, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. Albert, who lived in Palo Alto, Calif., was 82.

abstract: The head of Bayer's worldwide drug operations resigned today during a strategic upheaval intended to allow the company to reshape itself through joint ventures. Ebsworth, 48, after slightly more than two years in his current post, surprised analysts, who said he was highly regarded despite a string of high-profile disasters at Bayer's drug unit.

abstract: HATESHIP, FRIENDSHIP, COURTSHIP, LOVESHIP, MARRIAGE: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.) Many of the central characters in these nine tales start out by having a harsh hand dealt them, whether it's cancer, the suicide of an ailing husband or Alzheimer's disease, but somehow manage to find enduring value in their lives as they struggle through their darkest moments. This collection, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, is ''surely Munro's best yet,'' William H. Pritchard wrote here. Her ''vivid, external perceptions are complemented and balanced by a more exploratory, inwardly poetic kind of writing.''    GERMS: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War, by Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) The authors -- two current reporters for The Times and a former Times editor -- tell the story of biological weapons from anthrax to salmonella and the fight against them. ''The tone is somewhat alarmist, but because of the care with which the authors have assembled their case, not to mention our new sense of what is possible, even skeptical readers may have trouble sleeping easily after they finish it,'' Gideon Rose wrote here in 2001. Scourge: The Once and Future Threat of Smallpox, by Jonathan B. Tucker (Grove, $14), traces the history of smallpox from its earliest recorded outbreak in ancient Egypt to its eradication in 1980 and its possible reincarnation as a biological weapon. Last year our reviewer, Ed Regis, found this ''a concise, suspenseful and scientifically accurate narrative.''    CHESTER HIMES: A LIFE, by James Sallis. (Walker, $18.95.) In his ambitious series of Harlem crime novels featuring the detectives Coffin Ed Johnson and Grave Digger Jones, Chester Himes (1909-84) created his most incisive, radical and enduring fiction while finding an outlet for the pain and obsessions of his turbulent personal life. Last year in these pages Robert Polito called this a ''smart, conscientious, often stylish biography'' that is ''admirably tentative about motive and explanation.''    MRS. HOLLINGSWORTH'S MEN, by Padgett Powell. (Louisiana State University, $15.95.) In this novel, a Southern woman of a certain age looks back on the men in her mind's life, chief among them the great Confederate general Nathan Bedford Forrest. Her thoughts ''create a tumultuous narrative, full of the rancorous prejudices involved in responding to the world around you,'' Robert Kelly wrote in the Book Review in 2000. The result is ''a slim, sly deceiver of a book, full of mirth and wickedness.''    CARTER BEATS THE DEVIL, by Glen David Gold. (Hyperion, $14.95.) This first novel, built around a framework of real events that recapture the long-vanished world of vaudeville, tells of a dazzling, mysterious magician who tangles with a Secret Service agent who holds him responsible for the death of President Warren G. Harding. It is ''a grand story told well, in plain language that glows with bare-bones elegance,'' Stephanie Zacharek wrote here in 2001.    CULTIVATING DELIGHT: A Natural History of My Garden, by Diane Ackerman. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) In 52 lushly drawn but scientifically grounded sections, the author -- a poet by training -- follows her garden from spring through winter, ruminating on the stare of a cardinal or the prodigious oceanic journeys of the arctic tern. ''Reading Ackerman's book reminds us that we too can make our paradise here and that tranquillity can be achieved by contemplating the petals of a rose,'' Miranda Seymour said here last year.    SELDOM DISAPPOINTED: A Memoir, by Tony Hillerman. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) The author of the Jim Chee- Joe Leaphorn series of Navajo crime novels recalls, at 75, his hardscrabble Oklahoma upbringing, his service in World War II (he lost most of a foot and sight in one eye) and his long career as a newspaperman. '' 'Seldom Disappointed' is a splendid and disarming remembrance of things past,'' Timothy Foote wrote here in 2001.    DAVID BORING, by Daniel Clowes. (Pantheon, $16.95.) This comic book geared for adults revolves around a laconic 19-year-old whose wanderings in search of a lost lover take him deep into Hitchcock and David Lynch territory. In 2000 our reviewer, Dave Eggers, praised ''the perfect interplay'' between Clowes's ''tightly controlled artwork, the empty . . . rage simmering just beneath it, and just below that, a strangely simple yearning for simple and solid things, like, say, love.''   Scott Veale

abstract: The Ethicist column on obligation to repay one's mother's college loan, on disclosing whether one has yet learned certain computer program (S)
snippet: The Ethicist column on obligation to repay one's mother's college loan, on disclosing whether one has yet learned certain computer program (S)
lead_paragraph: After raising six kids, my mother divorced my father, went back to school and became a therapist. She never learned to manage money and eventually declared bankruptcy. The one debt that remained was a student loan. Now 75 and suffering from Alzheimer's, she's in an assisted-living facility paid for by Medicaid. None of us kids have more than a modest income. Are we obliged to pay her remaining debt? Robin Dellabough, Irvington, N.Y.

abstract: It would be tempting to describe the troubles besetting Rafael Belvedere (Ricardo Darín), the stressed-out protagonist of Juan José Campanella's comedy as emblematic of Argentina's precarious economic health. As the movie opens, Rafael, who is 42 and divorced with a young daughter, is fielding offers to buy the restaurant he runs in Buenos Aires. Then, out of the blue, he is felled by a heart attack. As he recovers, he is forced to re-examine his life and to decide his priorities. "Son of the Bride," an Academy Award nominee for best foreign film, may be as exhaustive a study of one man's midlife crisis as has ever been brought to the screen. But as the movie lopes along, exhaustive becomes exhausting. — Stephen Holden

abstract: QUEENS: Lawyer Accused Of Theft From Clients; MANHATTAN: Robbery Suspect Sought; MANHATTAN: 9 Accused Of Insurance Fraud; MANHATTAN: Labor Leaders Protest House Bill; NEW SEAT BELT LAW IN EFFECT; MANHATTAN: Arrest In Knife Assault;.
snippet: QUEENS: Lawyer Accused Of Theft From Clients; MANHATTAN: Robbery Suspect Sought; MANHATTAN: 9 Accused Of Insurance Fraud; MANHATTAN: Labor Leaders Protest House Bill; NEW SEAT BELT LAW IN EFFECT; MANHATTAN: Arrest In Knife Assault;.
lead_paragraph: QUEENS: LAWYER ACCUSED OF THEFT FROM CLIENTS A Long Island City lawyer has been charged with stealing from clients the city appointed him to represent, including an Alzheimer's patient and a teenager born with "massive birth defects." The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday that the lawyer, Robert B. Kress, 47, is accused of stealing more than $1.2 million over five years from six individuals whose finances he was hired to manage. Officials said the largest amount, $631,000, was stolen from a 67-year-old mentally ill man. A law enforcement official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Kress spent the money on expensive cars, a wine collection and vacation property in Maui. Mr. Kress, who did not return phone calls seeking comment, could face up to 25 years in prison if convicted. Hope Reeves (NYT)

abstract: NEW YORK BRONX: MAN KILLS GIRLFRIEND AND HIMSELF, POLICE SAY A man shot and killed his girlfriend yesterday before using the gun to fatally shoot himself in the head, the police said. The man, 24, whose name was not released pending notification of family, began to argue with his girlfriend, Stacey Green, 22, in a Wakefield apartment shortly before 1 a.m. yesterday, the authorities said. The police said the motive was unclear.   Jacob H. Fries (NYT).

abstract: Patricia Taylor Cuttings column offers advice on controlling slugs; drawing (M)
snippet: Patricia Taylor Cuttings column offers advice on controlling slugs; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR years, I believed the only positive thing to be said about slugs was that they are resilient. No matter how unfavorable the conditions for them -- droughts are particularly devastating -- their numbers never seem to diminish. After weeks of no summer rain, for example, slugs would somehow miraculously appear after the first downpour and devour all my newly planted lettuce seedlings.
headline.main: A Primer That's All About, Ugh, Slugs
headline.print_headline: CUTTINGS; A Primer That's All About, Ugh, Slugs

abstract: Shareholders of Elan Corp, Dublin-based specialty drug maker, have beaten down company's share price by two-thirds in week on concern about company's finances; Elan says its sales rose 22 percent in 2001, to $1.9 billion, but warns that profits will fall by one-third this year; estimates that if it includes two off-balance-sheet investments on its books, its debt will be half again as high--$3 billion instead of $2 billion--and its reported earnings will be nearly 40 percent lower; at least four shareholder suits have been filed against company, seeking class-action status; suits, including one filed in federal court in California by Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach and another in New York by Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, accuse Elan of using deceptive accounting to exaggerate its earnings; Elan's 55 joint ventures and partnerships have come under close scrutiny; Elan's fall has been difficult for whole Irish stock market; its market capitalization of nearly 17 billion euros ($14.8 billion) in January represented about one-quarter of entire Irish Stock Exchange; company is worth about 5.4 billion euros ($4.7 billion) on Feb 5 (M)

snippet: Caryn James reviews TV movie Door to Door, directed by Steven Schachter and starring William H Macy and Helen Mirren; movie is based on life of cerebral palsy victim Bill Porter; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: With reddish hair, enormous jug ears and a big goofy grin, William H. Macy looks like Howdy Doody come to life -- an irreverent association for a character who has cerebral palsy. abstract: Revolutionary partnership between nine New York City universities and research centers has built cutting edge Structural Biology Center in Harlem; powerful nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometers on-site give researchers more data in less time; chief operating officer Dr Willa Appel has also managed to secure additional funding from New York State and federal sources adding to appeal for good scientists to stay in area; photo (M)
snippet: Revolutionary partnership between nine New York City universities and research centers has built cutting edge Structural Biology Center in Harlem; powerful nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometers on-site give researchers more data in less time; c...
lead_paragraph: Like rockets awaiting a launching signal, three white towers pierce the floor of a former gymnasium on the City College campus at 133rd Street and Convent Avenue in Harlem. Beneath, gigantic concrete cylinders rooted to bedrock prevent their delicate innards from being jarred by passing subway trains. On the floor around each tower is painted a red line, a warning to anyone who steps inside that an intense magnetic field will lift keys faster than any pickpocket.

abstract: Ellyn Spragins column on how family ties can be frayed when adult children step in to assume control of finances of elderly parents; drawing (M)
snippet: Ellyn Spragins column on how family ties can be frayed when adult children step in to assume control of finances of elderly parents; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: THERE'S no light touch to bring to the topic of elderly parents. No humor in failing bodies, except the kind used in the birthday cards of younger people. You can read all you want about active seniors and ''zoomers,'' the new term for aging baby boomers, but most elderly parents are not rappelling off mountains or running marathons.
headline.main: Help for Elderly Parent Can Fray Family Ties
headline.print_headline: LOVE & MONEY; Help for Elderly Parent Can Fray Family Ties

abstract: Norman O Brown, erudite and spectacularly playful philosopher whose attempt to psychoanalyze nothing less than history itself entranced intellectuals, beguiled New Age seekers and sold many books, dies at age 89; photo (M)

abstract: FOR years, I believed the only positive thing to be said about slugs was that they are resilient. No matter how unfavorable the conditions for them -- droughts are particularly devastating -- their numbers never seem to diminish. After weeks of no summer rain, for example, slugs would somehow miraculously appear after the first downpour and devour all my newly planted lettuce seedlings.     In an effort to better know my enemy, I searched the Web and learned that scientists have been studying these slimy creatures for many years. It turns out that their brains allow them to distinguish between odors and tastes. The gene involved in this action is similar to a gene in our brains.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, I believed the only positive thing to be said about slugs was that they are resilient. No matter how unfavorable the conditions for them -- droughts are particularly devastating -- their numbers never seem to diminish. After weeks of no summer rain, for example, slugs would somehow miraculously appear after the first downpour and devour all my newly planted lettuce seedlings.

abstract: Best Bet      Eager to prove that there's more to the local dance scene than the ''Nutcracker'' in December, 35 companies formed the Long Island Dance Consortium two years ago. On Saturday and next Sunday, 14 of them will stage a ''Celebration of Dance -- 2002.'' The troupes, which include the Circle of Dance, the North Shore Dance Theater and the Long Island Dance Company, will perform at 8 p.m. Saturday and 3 p.m. next Sunday at Five Towns College in Dix Hills. Information: (631) 271-8423.    Festival Time      Port Washington celebrates its nautical past on Saturday with a Harborfest featuring music cruises on Manhasset Bay, a model-boat regatta and crafts shows from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. at the town dock and along Lower Main Street. Information: (516) 883-6566. History is the main draw in three other towns, too. In Riverhead, at Hallockville Museum Farm and Folklife Center on Sound Avenue, there is a Civil War Encampment that begins on Friday with programming for schools and continues from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Saturday and next Sunday, with battles and demonstrations of camp life. Information: (631) 298-5292. There's also a lot of fighting in Sag Harbor, where the 225th anniversary of Meig's Raid will be observed in a three-day celebration that begins on Friday as the Revolutionary War regiments set up their campsites. With tall ships in the harbor, on Saturday American ''soldiers'' in whale boats will attack the village and battle the British. On Sunday, the troops will march, battle and demonstrate tactical weapons. Information: (631) 725-0770. Finally, in Setauket, on Saturday the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities and the Three Village Historical Society stage a day of 18th-  and 19th-century ''living history'' from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Thompson House and the Swezey-Bayles House on North Country Road and around the Village Green. Information: (631) 692-4664.
lead_paragraph: Best Bet

abstract: For the Craft Museum  TUESDAY -- The songwriter Cy Coleman will perform at a black-tie dinner at the Pierre to raise money for the American Craft Museum and its educational programs. The evening begins at 7 with cocktails. Dinner at 8 will be followed by dancing to the music of Gerard Carelli and his orchestra. Tickets, $500, from (212) 956-3535, ext. 112.    Helping Crime Victims  TUESDAY -- A cocktail reception at the American Museum of Natural History will raise money for the Crime Victims Treatment Center, which provides counseling, legal services and other aid. Linda Fairstein, the former head of the Manhattan District Attorney's sex crimes unit, will be among those honored. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres will be served beginning at 6:30. Tickets, $150, from (212) 523-4728.
lead_paragraph: For the Craft Museum

lead_paragraph: EVERY year at this time, members of the Suquamish nation set up temporary roadside stands and transform the Port Madison reservation, just outside Seattle, into a bustling, booming market for fireworks. abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column, in light of latest findings on possible health risks of long-term hormone replacement therapy, offers advice on quitting such therapy and possible alternatives to relieve menopausal symptoms; drawing (M)
snippet: Jane Brody Personal Health column, in light of latest findings on possible health risks of long-term hormone replacement therapy, offers advice on quitting such therapy and possible alternatives to relieve menopausal symptoms; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Many women worried about the latest findings on the possible health risks of long-term hormone replacement are ready to abandon the therapy or have decided not to start it. But how? How can a woman stop hormones without suffering the menopausal symptoms that may have prompted her to start in the first place? What can a woman do instead to protect her bones, her heart or any other part of her that estrogen was supposed to help?

abstract: Dudley Clendinen article on Canterbury Tower, high-rise building in Tampa, Fla, for geriatric set; includes numerous amenities and offers nursing wing for residents who require high level of care; many are resigned to fact that this will be their last home and face life with courage and wit; eclectic mix of residents and lifestyles described; photo (special section, Retirement) (L)
snippet: Dudley Clendinen article on Canterbury Tower, high-rise building in Tampa, Fla, for geriatric set; includes numerous amenities and offers nursing wing for residents who require high level of care; many are resigned to fact that this will be their ...
lead_paragraph: FOR the last two years, I have lived about half the time in a geriatric high-rise building here called Canterbury Tower, with a crowd of pithy, brave, funny people who are, um -- not young -- and who have chosen to live in a place where they have to flip the levers on their mailboxes in the lobby each day to let the front desk know they are still alive. Living in places like this is what people in their late 70's and 80's and 90's who can afford it tend to do now. They sell their retirement homes and move into life-care towers and assisted-living complexes along the waterways and suburban highways of Florida and other states. Normally, they do it unaccompanied by children, writers or otherwise younger folks like me. I am 57. The average age in Canterbury is 86. That's a difference.
headline.main: The Canterbury Tales, Set in Florida
headline.print_headline: PLACES; The Canterbury Tales, Set in Florida

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    C.I.A. Has Broad Authority In Hunt for Terrorists  The lethal missile strike that killed a suspected leader of Al Qaeda in Yemen was carried out under broad authority that President Bush has given the C.I.A. over the past year to pursue the terror network well beyond the borders of Afghanistan, senior government officials said. The president was not asked to authorize the specific decision to fire the missile that killed Qaed Salim Sinan al-Harethi and five others, the officials said.   A1    Drones Would Be Used in War  In a war with Iraq, the Air Force would use the same missile-firing drones, called Predator planes, that killed a senior Qaeda leader in Yemen to attack Iraqi air defense radars, mobile Scud missile launchers and possibly sensitive targets in Baghdad, military officials said.   A16
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

lead_paragraph: Not long ago while doing morning rounds at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx, Edna Adams, a nurse's aide, knocked on a resident's door. As was her habit, when she didn't hear an answer, she pushed it open, and found two of her patients -- each over 80 and with Alzheimer's disease -- nude and making noisy, passionate love.

snippet: Hormone replacement options for women entering menopause are sorted out against backdrop of studies that have questioned value of hormone replacement; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR women reaching menopause, decisions about hormone replacement therapy -- whether to take it, how long, in which form and dose -- seem to be getting more complicated. New studies contradict old ones. Books, Web sites and advertisements for an array of products abound -- each pill said to be safer, more natural and more rejuvenating than the last.

abstract: Brief reviews of films being shown this holiday season; photos
snippet: Brief reviews of films being shown this holiday season; photos
lead_paragraph: An epic battle of good versus evil set in a prehistoric landscape; a brutal murder that prompts the victim's grief-stricken parents to consider vigilante justice for a killer who may get off with a light sentence; a struggle for dominance between two soldiers stranded in a trench between battle lines as media vultures descend: those are the themes of three of the most powerful films released for holiday consumption. Although it might appear otherwise, those films -- ''The Lord of the Rings,'' ''In the Bedroom'' and ''No Man's Land'' -- were all completed before the events of Sept. 11. Yet all three reverberate with a prescience that their creators could not have anticipated and convey what might be called a post-traumatic resonance.

lead_paragraph: Menopause is not a disease, as doctors often point out, only an inevitability of middle age. But for most women, it does come with symptoms, as the body is weaned from its customary diet of estrogen. Some of these can be more than a little annoying: sudden spikes in temperature that make the face flush and the sweat flow; soaked sheets at 3 a.m.; vaginal dryness that causes incessant pain and itching.

abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 15.    Now Playing    * ''ALI,'' starring Will Smith, Jamie Foxx and Jon Voight. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 158 minutes). This film is a breakthrough for Mr. Mann. Based on the life of Muhammad Ali, it is Mr. Mann's first movie with feeling; his overwhelming love of its subject will turn audiences into exuberant, thrilled fight crowds. That subject is a man whose mesmerizing surfeit of supreme athleticism, beauty and moral and physical courage -- and enchanting lack of humility -- had no modern equivalent. The film offers a stunning re-creation of the bouts that Ali fought. And Mr. Smith as the Greatest captures the fighter's musicality, pausing in mid-syllable while ranting and exhaling to punch things up and turn even a joke into something operatic (Elvis Mitchell).

abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.    Now Playing    ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

abstract: "[T]he world of Tony Soprano is a kind of postmodern 'Middlemarch,' whose inhabitants' moral and spiritual development (or devolution) unfolds within and against the norms of a parochial social milieu . . ."
snippet: "[T]he world of Tony Soprano is a kind of postmodern 'Middlemarch,' whose inhabitants' moral and spiritual development (or devolution) unfolds within and against the norms of a parochial social milieu . . ."
lead_paragraph: Midway through the first season of The Sopranos , the protagonist`s psychotherapist, Jennifer Melfi, has a not-exactly-traditional family dinner with her middle-class Italian parents, son, and ex-husband Richard La Penna ["The Legend of Tennessee Moltisanti"/1008]. She lets slip (hmm!) that one of her patients is a mobster, much to Richard`s consternation. An activist in Italian anti-defamation politics, he is incensed at the opprobrium the Mafia has brought on all Italians. What is the point, he protests, of trying to help such a person? In a subsequent scene he contemptuously dismisses Jennifer and her profession for purveying "cheesy moral relativism" in the face of evil. His challenge boldly proclaims what until then has been implicit: the richest and most compelling piece of television-no, of popular culture-that I`ve encountered in the past twenty years is a meditation on the nature of morality, the possibility of redemption, and the legacy of Freud.
headline.main: 'This Thing of Ours'
headline.print_headline: 'This Thing of Ours'

abstract: "The aim of this book is to argue that Huxley was right, that the most significant threat posed by contemporary biotechnology is the possibility that it will alter human nature . . ."
snippet: "The aim of this book is to argue that Huxley was right, that the most significant threat posed by contemporary biotechnology is the possibility that it will alter human nature . . ."
lead_paragraph: Iwas born in 1952, right in the middle of the American baby boom. For any person growing up as I did in the middle decades of the twentieth century, the future and its terrifying possibilities were defined by two books, George Orwell's 1984 (first published in 1949), and Aldous Huxley's Brave New World (published in 1932).
headline.main: 'Our Posthuman Future'
headline.print_headline: 'Our Posthuman Future'

abstract: Milton Berle, brash comedian who became first star of television as beloved 'Uncle Miltie' on Texaco Star Theater from 1948 to 1954, dies at age of 93; began his career in vaudeville, nightclubs, radio and films before igniting national craze for new medium of television in late 1940's; his long career recalled; photos (L)
snippet: Milton Berle, brash comedian who became first star of television as beloved 'Uncle Miltie' on Texaco Star Theater from 1948 to 1954, dies at age of 93; began his career in vaudeville, nightclubs, radio and films before igniting national craze for ...
lead_paragraph: Milton Berle, the brash comedian who emerged from vaudeville, nightclubs, radio and films to become the first star of television, igniting a national craze for the new medium in the late 1940's, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.
headline.main: Milton Berle, TV's First Star As 'Uncle Miltie,' Dies at 93
headline.print_headline: Milton Berle, TV's First Star As 'Uncle Miltie,' Dies at 93

abstract: Emily Yoffe article on aftrmath of crash of Air Florida airliner shortly after takeoff from Washington's National Airport on Jan 13, 1982; plane hit bridge over Potomac and sank into river; 74 of 79 people on plane and four people on bridge were killed; survivors and family members of those killed tell of relief, guilt, joy and anger that followed, and they say there is no blueprint for grief one faces after such sudden, public loss; Lenny Skutnik, bystander who briefly became world-famous after diving into river to rescue drowning woman, does not regard himself as hero and retains some bitterness toward press for turning him into commodity; photos (L)
snippet: Emily Yoffe article on aftrmath of crash of Air Florida airliner shortly after takeoff from Washington's National Airport on Jan 13, 1982; plane hit bridge over Potomac and sank into river; 74 of 79 people on plane and four people on bridge were k...
lead_paragraph: She comes to lunch holding a frayed manila envelope she usually keeps hidden in the basement. That's where she stores what's left of the life she didn't get to live. She is 47, small and pretty, with deep-set green eyes and honey-colored hair. She doesn't want her name used because she hasn't yet told her children that when she was a young woman, before she met their father, she was in love with another man. His name was Robert Silberglied, and he was a 35-year-old scientist, an expert in butterflies, a protégé of E.O. Wilson, the famous biologist. On the morning of Jan. 13, 1982, Silberglied asked her to marry him, and she said yes.

abstract: Animal rights advocates present a compelling vision of a more moral world. But this vision is ecologically foolhardy — and based on a naive definition of animal happiness.
snippet: Animal rights advocates present a compelling vision of a more moral world. But this vision is ecologically foolhardy — and based on a naive definition of animal happiness.
lead_paragraph: The first time I opened Peter Singer's ''Animal Liberation,'' I was dining alone at the Palm, trying to enjoy a rib-eye steak cooked medium-rare. If this sounds like a good recipe for cognitive dissonance (if not indigestion), that was sort of the idea. Preposterous as it might seem, to supporters of animal rights, what I was doing was tantamount to reading ''Uncle Tom's Cabin'' on a plantation in the Deep South in 1852.
headline.main: An Animal's Place
headline.print_headline: An Animal's Place

abstract: Michael Pollan article takes issue with Peter Singer's book Animal Liberation, which expresses view that eating, wearing or otherwise killing animals is speciesism, or form of discrimination as indefensible as racism; contends animal liberation is no longer fringe idea it was when book was published in 1975, with 37 states having laws making animal cruelty a crime; says that while many people seem eager to extend moral consideration to animals, more suffering is being inflicted on them--in factory farms and laboratories--than at any other time in history; says as animals figure less in everyday lives, pets notwithstanding, disconnect between, for example, meat and animals grows; reviews, and rejects, several arguments in Singer's book, drawing conclusions that differences between people and animals are sufficient to exclude them from moral consideration afforded to people; says suffering of humans is more difficult to justify because emotions such as dread combined with unique quality of human consciousness carry weight in calculus; argues that human pain differs from animal pain by order of magnitude and ability to imagine alternatives; describes conditions on factory farms where he contends animals are treated as machines incapable of feeling pain and subjected to hellish conditions; also describes conditions on farm where animals are treated humanely; says animal happiness appears to derive from their being able to express unique character and believes animal rights activists betray ignorance of workings of nature on this point; says no other country has industrialized and dehumanized animal farming as America has and believes if people were aware of horrors, they would eat less meat; says knowledge gained through research has led him to limit intake to nonindustrially-raised meat; photos (M)
snippet: Michael Pollan article takes issue with Peter Singer's book Animal Liberation, which expresses view that eating, wearing or otherwise killing animals is speciesism, or form of discrimination as indefensible as racism; contends animal liberation is...

abstract: Correction of Feb 14 article about link between Alzheimer's disease and high blood levels of homocysteine; foods that provide certain B vitamins noted
snippet: Correction of Feb 14 article about link between Alzheimer's disease and high blood levels of homocysteine; foods that provide certain B vitamins noted
lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about a link between Alzheimer's disease and high blood levels of a substance called homocysteine referred incorrectly to the foods that provide certain B vitamins, all of them able to lower homocysteine levels. Fruits and leafy vegetables provide the B vitamin called folic acid, but not vitamins B6 or B12. Vitamin B6 is found in dried yeast, liver, organ meats, whole-grain cereals, fish and legumes; vitamin B12 occurs in liver, organ meat and other meat, eggs and dairy products.
headline.main: Corrections
headline.print_headline: Corrections
